node.title: Victorian government's pandemic bill to become law after passing through parliament
node.alt: Victorian Parliament with Spring St sign and green traffic light in foreground
node.description: After weeks of negotiations and substantial amendments, the Victorian government's controversial pandemic legislation has cleared its last hurdle.
node.content:
["The Victorian government's controversial pandemic laws have officially passed the through the state parliament.", "The laws, which replace the state of emergency powers, passed 20 votes to 18, with the support of four crossbenchers.\u00a0", "It comes after days of debate and a marathon sitting that lasted 21 hours in order to pass several amendments.\u00a0", "The legislation will now be passed to the governor for royal assent\u00a0to become law.", "Health Minister Martin Foley said the government\u00a0did\u00a0not expect to use the new powers before December 15\u00a0when the state of emergency expires.", "Victoria will be the first state in Australia to have pandemic-specific legislation, giving the government of the day the legal framework it needs to manage\u00a0health emergencies, including vaccine mandates and mask rules.", "The legislation will give Victoria's premier and health minister the power to declare a pandemic and enforce restrictions.", "The proposal first came to light in late October, and in its original form, it elicited criticism from legal groups, the state's ombudsman, the opposition\u00a0and others concerned about potential human rights breaches.", "The state government spruiked the bill as one that would increase transparency, but its opponents raised concerns about powers granted to the premier and health minister and called for greater oversight and checks to be included.", "Large protests that were held in opposition to the change on the steps of Parliament House attracted many thousands of people, and violent imagery was used by some protesters.", "Dozens of\u00a0amendments were made to the original proposal as a result of negotiations between the state government and crossbench MPs such as the Reason Party's Fiona Patton, Animal Justice Party's Andy Meddick and the Greens' leader Samantha Ratnam.", "In recent days,\u00a0Transport Matters MP Rod Barton agreed to back the bill after securing further changes, and his support ultimately led to its passage through the upper house today.", "The state opposition was highly critical of the bill, and\u00a0while the Victorian Bar backed the safeguards introduced to the bill via the negotiations, president\u00a0R\u00f3is\u00edn Annesley said concerns remained about some of the powers it outlined.", "", "
